10.73.text:
>> Dean Scott Angle:
If you can take a seat,
we're about to get started.

19.54.text:
And if we could try and move
everyone in from the foyer

23.02.text:
and get a seat, we'll start
in just about two minutes.

52.69.text:
Okay, well I want
to welcome everyone.

55.59.text: I am the Dean of the

56.21.text:
College of Agricultural
and Environmental Sciences,

58.79.text:
and today is our
D.W. Brooks lecture day.

61.59.text:
This is the highlight 
of the year for the

63.79.text:
College of Agricultural and
Environmental Sciences,

66.07.text:
and I want to thank you all
for being a part of this.

68.83.text:
We're going to begin this
morning by recognizing some

71.59.text:
of our award winners who
are many of your colleagues

76.05.text:
in the college and
around this campus.

78.92.text:
We will then be hearing from our
D. W. Brooks lecturer this year,

86.10.text:
But before I do that, I want
to give you a little bit

88.16.text: of background on D. W. Brooks.

90.04.text:
He was someone that I never
had the opportunity to meet.

92.34.text:
He died just a few years
before I came to Georgia.

95.76.text:
But he was a very special person
to our college, this university,

100.41.text:
and the great State of Georgia,
as well as American agriculture.

104.71.text:
In 1922 he taught agronomy
in the College of Agricultural

109.93.text:
and Environmental Sciences
at the University of Georgia.

112.04.text:
And he was still in
his teens at that time.

115.28.text:
And he was still
teaching at the

116.50.text:
University of Georgia 
at the age of 97.

120.10.text:
So he holds simultaneously
the record

123.06.text:
for being both the youngest
and oldest professor

129.68.text:
Between that time 1997
when he passed away,

133.69.text:
he had obviously a very
distinguished career beyond just

139.93.text:
He was the founder of Gold Kist,
the poultry company in the state

143.60.text: that went on to be one

144.44.text:
of the largest poultry
producers in the country.

147.74.text:
He developed Cotton Southern, or
Cotton States Insurance Company

153.04.text:
to make sure that farmers had
access to good money management.

158.18.text:
He was the advisor to
seven U.S. Presidents

165.22.text:
He's held many, many positions
in a variety of other countries,

169.90.text: and he's won many of the honors

172.16.text:
that are bestowed upon
agriculturists throughout

177.44.text:
When we think about
name changing,

181.86.text:
industry changing
individuals like D. W. Brooks

185.90.text:
or Norman Borlaug who
you'll be hearing more

188.02.text: about in just a few minutes,

190.47.text:
we've got some wonderful
individuals in our college

192.75.text:
as well who have made
great contributions

197.39.text:
And one of the things that we
would like to do is ask them

200.43.text:
to come in now, and I'll
call out their names

202.54.text: and recognize each one of them.

205.18.text:
We'll be recognizing
them a little more

206.73.text:
in an awards banquet
later on today over lunch.

210.00.text: So let me begin with that.

211.74.text:
And I'm going to call
each of their names

213.20.text: and if they could walk up front

214.50.text:
and take a seat in
the front row.

217.38.text:
So our D. W. Brooks faculty
awards for Excellence

220.36.text:
in Teaching are
Dr. Terry Centner.

223.40.text:
Terry if you can
start your way up.

225.22.text:
He's a Professor of Agriculture
and Applied Economics.

229.30.text:
Our faculty award for Excellence
in Research is Dr. Tim Grey.

233.94.text:
He's a Professor of
Crop and Soil Sciences.

237.12.text:
In Extension it's
Dr. Dennis Hancock.

239.12.text:
He's an Associate Professor
in Crop and Soil Sciences.

243.83.text:
For Public Service
Extension, Janet Hollingsworth.

247.86.text:
She's our County Extension
Coordinator for Appling County,

250.96.text:
and she's a Family and
Consumer Sciences Agent

253.68.text:
in both Appling and
Ware Counties.

257.04.text:
And for Global Programs
Ignacy Misztal.

259.62.text:
He's a Professor of
Animal and Dairy Sciences.

264.48.text:
For our Outstanding Academic
Advisor it's Dr. Frank Flanders.

271.89.text:
of Agriculture Leadership
Education and Communications.

277.40.text:
College of Agricultural
and Environmental Sciences

279.44.text:
staff awards for Administrative
and Professional Support,

284.70.text:
He's the Director of Student
and Employer Engagement

287.98.text:
in the college of, or excuse me,
the Office of Academic Affairs.

292.22.text:
Technical Support
is Mr. Jay Bauer.

295.20.text:
He's our Senior Graphics
Designer in the college's

299.60.text:
Office of Communications 
and Creative Services.

303.36.text:
For Skilled Trades, we have
two individuals, Mr. CJ O'Mara

310.74.text:
He is a Senior Ag
Specialist and individual

315.57.text: for the J. Phil Campbell Farm.

321.10.text:
D. W. Brooks Diversity Award
Faculty is Cesar Escalante.

332.04.text:
And for our student
it's Brittnee Thirkield.

337.20.text:
She's a graduate
student in our

338.94.text:
Department of Food Science 
and Technology.

340.97.text:
Let's give all of our award
winners a great big round

353.91.text:
When we began searching
for a person

356.06.text:
to deliver today's
D. W. Brooks lecture,

358.94.text:
one individual quickly
rose to the top.

362.15.text:
As many of you know,
we have had a number

365.45.text:
of past World Food Prize
winners as a speaker

371.07.text:
And this year we wanted to
hear directly from the founder

375.30.text:
and leader of the program
that many of us consider

378.55.text:
to be the Nobel Prize
of agriculture.

382.74.text:
Dr. Ken Quinn, Ambassador
Kenneth Quinn embodies so many

387.72.text:
of the principles and commitment
to excellence and to agriculture

392.15.text:
that D. W. Brooks and 
Dr. Norman Borlaug have demonstrated

399.18.text:
Kenneth Quinn is the
former Ambassador

405.24.text:
And during his diplomatic
career, Ken Quinn served

408.07.text:
as a Rural Development
Advisor in the Mekong Delta.

413.10.text:
He was on the National Security
Council staff at the White House

417.10.text:
as the Narcotics Counselor
at the U.S. Mission

421.09.text: to the United Nations in Vienna.

424.04.text: For four years he was Chairman

425.82.text:
of the U.S. Inter-agency
Task Force on POW and MIAs.

430.47.text:
And as Director of Iowa SHARES,
the humanitarian campaign

434.44.text:
that sent Iowa doctors, nurses,
medical supplies and food

447.21.text:
He has led just an
absolutely fascinating life.

451.98.text:
Dr. Quinn emerged from
these experiences as one

454.62.text:
of the U.S. Government's
foremost experts on Indochina.

461.44.text:
Dr. Amrit Bart's
wife is Vietnamese,

465.06.text:
and at dinner last night
he walked up to her

469.66.text:
and he began speaking
directly to her in Vietnamese.

473.19.text:
And I think she was as blown
away as the rest of us

476.49.text:
that he had such a command
of, for those of you

480.29.text:
who know anything about
the Vietnamese language,

482.48.text:
it is one of the most
difficult languages to learn.

486.60.text:
Dr. Quinn has acted
as an interpreter

488.91.text:
for President Gerald
Ford at the White House

491.04.text:
and personally negotiated
the first ever entry

494.12.text:
of a U.S. personnel into a
Vietnamese prison to search

500.33.text:
He was also a member of the
first U.S. team to gain entry

503.37.text:
to a former Soviet
prison in Russia.

507.15.text:
Ambassador Quinn
rose to become one

508.89.text:
of the most decorated
Foreign Service officers

512.28.text:
Recognized for the
important role he played

514.32.text:
in humanitarian endeavors,
as well as for his actions

522.79.text:
He has received the Secretary
of State's Award for Heroism

528.52.text:
to protect American citizens
exposed to danger in Cambodia,

532.96.text:
as well as the four
life-saving rescues

535.40.text:
in which he participated
in Vietnam.

538.36.text:
He has been the only civilian
to ever receive the U.S. Medal,

542.30.text:
excuse me, the U.S. Army Air
Medal for his participation

551.17.text:
He's also the only
Foreign Service officer

553.47.text:
to ever have three times
received the American Foreign

557.06.text:
Service Association
Rivkin and Herter Award

569.47.text:
with the State Department
Foreign Service,

572.35.text:
he became leader of the
World Food Prize Foundation.

576.66.text:
Inspired by the vision
of Dr. Norman Borlaug,

579.31.text:
the founder of the World Food
Prize Ambassador Quinn set

582.67.text:
out by building an
annual $250,000 award

587.28.text:
into the Nobel Prize
for Food and Agriculture.

591.84.text:
So with that, I would like
to invite Ambassador Quinn

595.23.text:
to the podium to deliver the
2014 D. W. Brooks lecture.

607.50.text:
>> Ambassador Kenneth Quinn:
Thank you Dean Angle.

614.46.text:
he'd be down there shaking
all your hands and telling you

617.29.text:
to keep it up and reach for
the stars as he always did.

620.61.text:
So it's wonderful to be here
on the university campus again.

625.96.text: I was here in 1979 very briefly.

628.91.text: But it's nice to be back.

630.83.text:
And I was out there
during the reception,

633.21.text:
and I heard someone saying this
is the happiest day of the year.

638.19.text:
And I thought, wow,
Brooks lecture.

640.86.text:
They must have heard something
about me to have that there.

644.49.text: And then the next comment was,

647.02.text:
that's because there are no more
political ads on TV after today.

651.95.text:
So, yes. And I'm from Iowa,
and we can't wait for there

657.85.text: to be no more political ads.

659.37.text:
But, I hope everybody, at least
everybody who's an American

663.83.text:
citizen and a Georgia
citizen have voted today.

667.94.text:
You know voting is a little
bit like food in America.

671.78.text:
Two things we take
for granted, right.

673.62.text:
Always going to be enough
food and always, our politics,

679.98.text:
But I worked in Cambodia where
people starved, and where to go

684.94.text: to vote you had to run the risk

687.28.text:
of the Khmer Rouge
terrorists trying to kill you.

691.34.text:
And people went out and were
really brave to do that.

694.05.text:
They changed the course of
direction of their country.

696.70.text:
So it's always good
to be reminded of that

699.97.text:
and what a great
privilege we have to live

703.34.text:
in a democracy even though we
wish those negative ads weren't

707.51.text: always out there on TV and that.

709.95.text:
So, I'm really honored
to be able

714.11.text:
to give the D. W.
Brooks lecture.

715.65.text: Dean Angle thank you so much.

717.63.text:
There I know Glen Burton
gave the first one.

719.88.text:
And that Dr. Borlaug
gave a lecture here,

725.43.text:
And Jimmy Carter is
part of the connection

728.62.text: that the World Food Prize has.

730.65.text:
He's a member of our
counsel of advisors.

733.43.text:
We also have one
member of our staff.

744.32.text:
of the entire World
Food Prize staff is

746.50.text: in this room with you today.

748.49.text:
But Lisa Fleming is a grad
of the University of Georgia.

752.21.text:
And through her we also have
links to two artists here.

756.59.text:
So the Art Rosenbaum, I don't
know I didn't get a chance

760.37.text:
to see the mural he
did at the

762.41.text:
Center for Humanities called
the World at Large.

766.11.text:
But he did a Borlaug poster
for us that's on the left.

768.97.text:
And Greg Benson who's also a
Georgia graduate did another

774.61.text:
And we also have a couple of
students who I'll mention later

778.27.text:
but who have been in our youth
programs they're from Georgia.

783.49.text: So we've got a small connection.

785.32.text:
But I've got one other
connection I want to tell you

787.52.text:
about and that is
from Dean Rusk.

790.93.text:
So I don't know how many of you
were around when Dean Rusk came

793.95.text:
to the faculty and that, but he
now has a distinguished center

798.27.text: at the law school about him.

801.36.text:
And so the reason
I want to tell you

804.47.text:
about Dean Rusk's connection
is that I grew up in the city.

809.61.text:
I was born in the
Bronx, New York.

812.03.text:
My dad moved to, took a
job in the Middle West,

814.53.text: and we moved to Dubuque, Iowa.

816.72.text:
I have no connection
to agriculture,

819.48.text:
unlike probably everybody
else in the room,

821.88.text:
I didn't want to
study agriculture.

824.17.text:
I had no interest in working on
a farm or have anything to do.

830.31.text: I took the Foreign Service exam

832.51.text:
and passed, passed
the oral exam.

836.32.text:
And my vision was of
diplomatic sugar plums.

841.58.text:
I was going to be going
to London or Paris.

845.62.text:
And I'd be in these
chandeliered ballrooms.

851.17.text:
and discussing the nuances
of international affairs,

854.84.text:
which is what I thought
diplomats did.

858.30.text:
And then I got to
the State Department

861.11.text:
where Dean Rusk was
Secretary of State.

864.00.text:
And I found out that
he had agreed

867.56.text:
that they would send Foreign
Service officers to Vietnam.

872.44.text:
And particularly if you
were male and single

881.01.text:
and you'd never been
in the military.

883.72.text:
And before I knew 
what happened,

886.00.text:
I was being trained
in Vietnamese.

888.15.text:
And it is hard as
the Dean mentioned.

892.36.text:
And I wasn't a very
good student.

895.18.text:
And ten months later
I'm on a plane.

899.82.text:
when you were a Foreign Service
officer, you're going to work

905.05.text:
I don't know if they have aperitifs, 
but it'd be alright."

909.53.text:
No, so you're going to go
out to a regional capital,

915.17.text:
Well no, then I said well
maybe I'm going to be

925.66.text:
And I found myself out as a
District Senior Advisor heading

932.17.text:
a ten member U.S. military
advisory team in Sadec Province

939.69.text:
in the middle of
the Mekong Delta.

943.36.text:
And they said just,
the job is easy.

946.19.text:
Just go out defeat the
Viet Cong insurgence,

949.83.text:
reform the administration
and win the hearts and minds

953.39.text:
of the people so
we can win the war.

956.28.text: And usually when I tell people

957.73.text:
that story they say now I
understand what the problem was

965.74.text:
And I had eight villages
where I was the advisor.

971.64.text:
And we worked the
Vietnamese government.

974.01.text:
And there were, you know,
Viet Cong underground.

977.63.text:
And we had, you know, used B52
bombs and boots on the ground.

983.97.text: You never could get rid of them.

986.88.text:
And then, by serendipity, by
chance, two things happened.

995.50.text:
Number one, the Green Revolution
came to Southeast Asia.

1001.44.text:
The same miracle as Norman
Borlaug was doing miracle wheat

1006.64.text:
to take it to India, a guy named
Hank Beachell from Nebraska was

1011.83.text:
at the International
Rice Research Institute,

1014.64.text:
and he came up with
IR-8 miracle rice.

1020.46.text:
And IR-8 miracle rice now
could be grown in half the time

1030.54.text:
You could get a crop
in three months,

1033.15.text:
so you could get two crops in a
year, plus have enough time left

1037.01.text:
over to grow melons or other
kind of fruit or vegetables.

1041.52.text:
And suddenly, farmers
could have the opportunity

1046.58.text:
of having surplus produce,
surplus crops, sell it,

1052.24.text:
have money to help lift
them out of poverty.

1055.42.text:
So that's the one
thing that's happening.

1056.89.text:
And we had, you know, ag
advisors who are coming to try

1060.62.text:
to convince farmers
using regular extension

1064.75.text:
Because if I touch the IR-8,
the plants knew instinctively.

1071.33.text:
But, and then the
other, just by chance,

1075.09.text:
is there was an old
French road that went

1081.01.text:
And it was in a terrible
state of disrepair.

1084.48.text:
There were all these
canals there.

1086.15.text:
There needed to be
bridges over it.

1088.06.text: And so we were fixing the road.

1090.58.text:
And we had engineers
down doing that.

1093.38.text:
And somewhere it just
got scheduled that way.

1096.68.text: And so as I went around,

1099.24.text:
I observed what became
the lesson of my life.

1104.63.text:
Because I saw that we had fixed
the road through four villages,

1110.72.text:
and everywhere we
fixed the road,

1117.86.text:
And where the road
stopped,the IR-8 rice stopped.

1121.67.text:
There wasn't any sign that
said no IR-8 rice after this.

1126.10.text:
It just was that somehow the
technology flowed down that road

1132.67.text:
in a way that I couldn't
totally explain,

1135.26.text:
but you could see it
demonstrated before your eyes.

1138.92.text:
And I saw this and
wanted to know more

1144.98.text:
And you would see the
impact, because now trucks

1148.35.text:
of course could come
down form Saigon.

1151.32.text:
They could go to the farm
gate to buy from farmers.

1155.40.text:
And beyond that, the Extension
workers could get down.

1159.96.text:
Now there were little taxis
that went from hamlet to hamlet.

1163.79.text:
So kids could stay
in school longer.

1165.82.text:
You saw every farmhouse
everywhere they're using

1170.12.text:
Now the farmers have
got metal roofing

1172.14.text:
because they've got extra
money to buy the metal sheeting

1175.70.text: to go on top of their roof.

1176.89.text:
The structures, the
houses, look more sturdy.

1182.73.text: You can see even in a year

1184.32.text:
or two how better
nourished they were.

1188.74.text:
And child mortality goes
down because now moms

1191.79.text:
with sick kids can get them out
to medical help or the doctor

1195.49.text:
or to the pharmacy
in time to intervene.

1201.38.text:
And, and somehow in
all of this, the roads

1208.82.text:
and rice undercut the
Viet Cong guerillas.

1216.79.text:
Now it used to be that
you could go to a lot

1218.74.text:
of these villages during the
day if you took security,

1222.07.text: but you didn't go at night.

1224.32.text: Now you could go day and night.

1226.18.text:
And you could go
without security.

1228.94.text:
Somehow this ability to
see other opportunities,

1233.57.text:
to be able to go back and forth,
to see the reality outside

1238.53.text:
undercut the Viet Cong in a way
that the bombs and the troops

1241.93.text:
on the ground and the enhanced
military technology could not.

1249.89.text:
all of that progress
stopped along with it.

1252.94.text: And if you go beyond that,

1254.38.text:
if you drive your four
wheel drive vehicle

1258.36.text:
across through the
canal, or you walked,

1260.20.text:
went across on a little sand
pan and road on the back

1262.46.text:
of a motorbike, whatever,
is you'd see

1272.80.text:
And the Viet Cong were
just as strong as ever.

1277.90.text:
And I took that with me as
a lesson that would endure.

1283.98.text:
And it sort of led to
a conversion for me.

1287.94.text:
So if I was going to
write some memoir,

1290.79.text:
my chapter here would be
called, you know,

1292.87.text:
"A Foot Soldier in 
the Green Revolution."

1297.78.text:
I was seeing what the impact
could be with my eyes.

1301.90.text:
And I ended up, I actually was
assigned to go to Western Europe

1306.97.text:
and work in one of
those fancy embassies.

1310.07.text:
And I told the State Department
I don't want to do that.

1313.79.text: I want to stay in Vietnam.

1315.33.text:
Now many of you may
know that when you show

1318.29.text:
such a clear instance of
mental instability, you know,

1323.20.text:
or organizations bring
you back right away.

1325.28.text:
But they were desperate for
guys to stay in Vietnam.

1328.43.text:
So I stayed, and I
stayed for six years.

1331.78.text:
And it changed the
course of my life.

1334.19.text:
And I saw the critical
relationship of agriculture

1348.42.text: And I carried it with me.

1350.14.text:
And my life and my career
focused on Indochina.

1354.90.text: And I came back to this in 1990

1359.08.text:
when I became Deputy
Assistant Secretary of State.

1363.96.text:
The Khmer Rouge had
ruled Cambodia

1367.24.text: for four and a half years.

1370.23.text:
They had caused the
deaths of about two million

1373.29.text:
out of seven million people
in that period of time.

1377.22.text:
The entire country was
tumultuously turned upside down.

1382.90.text:
And despite the fact that
200,000 North Vietnamese troops,

1387.21.text:
remember the greatest jungle
fighting army in history,

1390.35.text:
had spent a decade
trying to get rid

1392.23.text: of the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia.

1394.44.text: They gave up and went home.

1398.34.text:
the international community
came back to Cambodia,

1402.26.text:
there were 25,000 Khmer Rouge
all over the countryside.

1409.75.text:
in the countryside except
the towns and the main roads.

1414.24.text:
And I went to the Prime Minister
and got my aid colleagues,

1418.33.text:
and I had $11 million of
aid budget, not very much.

1422.13.text: And I said, take this and go

1424.13.text:
and rent all the road
grading equipment you can find

1426.83.text:
in Thailand, drive it in, let's
do contracts for highways.

1433.67.text:
and let's start bringing
it in and taking it

1438.90.text:
And it's like the way that the
roads that we were building,

1445.17.text:
these new rural roads,
were like the bloodstream

1448.45.text:
that allows chemotherapy to
go to the cancerous tumor.

1453.96.text:
Because once as we built
the roads and got there,

1457.26.text:
that flow of information,
of life, of education,

1461.84.text:
of uplifting people went
out into the countryside

1466.04.text:
and into all these places
where the Khmer Rouge were

1469.39.text:
and undercutting them
and devastating them.

1472.78.text:
And so nine years later
as I was about to leave,

1475.82.text:
in March of 1999,
now I'm Ambassador,

1480.35.text:
and the last Khmer
Rouge surrendered.

1489.01.text:
the single greatest genocidal
